org.apache.drill.exec.physical.rowSet

Class TestHyperVectorReaders

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.apache.drill.test.BaseTest
      • org.apache.drill.test.DrillTest
        • org.apache.drill.test.SubOperatorTest
          • org.apache.drill.exec.physical.rowSet.TestHyperVectorReaders

  • public class TestHyperVectorReaders
extends SubOperatorTest
    Test the reader mechanism that reads rows indexed via an SV4. SV4's introduce an additional level of indexing: each row may come from a different batch. The readers use the SV4 to find the root batch and vector, then must navigate downward from that vector for maps, repeated maps, lists, unions, repeated lists, nullable vectors and variable-length vectors.

    This test does not cover repeated vectors; those tests should be added.

    • Constructor Detail

      • TestHyperVectorReaders

        public TestHyperVectorReaders()

    • Method Detail

      • testRequired

        public void testRequired()
        Test the simplest case: a top-level required vector. Has no contained vectors. This test focuses on the SV4 indirection mechanism itself.

      • testVarWidth

        public void testVarWidth()

      • testOptional

        public void testOptional()
        Test a nullable varchar. Requires multiple indirections:
        • From the SV4 to the nullable vector.
        • From the nullable vector to the bits vector.
        • From the nullable vector to the data vector.
        • From the data vector to the offset vector.
        • From the data vector to the values vector.
        All are coordinated by the vector index and vector accessors. This test verifies that each of the indirections does, in fact, work as expected.

      • testRepeated

        public void testRepeated()
        Test an array to test the indirection from the repeated vector to the array offsets vector and the array values vector. (Uses varchar to add another level of indirection to the data offset and data values vectors.)

      • testMap

        public void testMap()
        Maps are an interesting case. The hyper-vector wrapper holds a mirror-image of the map members. So, we can reach the map members either via the vector wrappers or the original map vector.

      • testRepeatedMap

        public void testRepeatedMap()

      • testUnion

        public void testUnion()
